context.setting: Hospital break room at 2 AM during quiet moment between emergencies
context.background: Sarah's elderly mother fell at home, sister calling from emergency room
context.tension_point: Family emergency while Sarah is on-call and can't leave hospital immediately
context.expected_outcome: Arrange care for mother while managing work responsibilities and guilt

participants.name: Lisa Chen

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Speaks rapidly when upset, provides medical details she's overheard
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more emotional and demands immediate action
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'Sarah, you need to' and 'The doctors here said' often
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice breaks when describing mother's condition

sample_dialogue: Sarah, you need to get here now - Mom's asking for you and she's really scared.
The doctors here said something about possible hip fracture - I don't understand everything.
I can't handle this alone - you're the doctor, you know what questions to ask!

participants.name: Sarah Chen

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Asks clinical questions while fighting emotional responses
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more clinical to cope with personal stress
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'What exactly did they' and 'I need to know' frequently
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice wavers between professional and personal tone

sample_dialogue: What exactly did they say about her vital signs and pain level?
I need to know if she's stable - Lisa, try to stay calm and give me facts.
I'm stuck here until 6 AM but I'll call the attending there to check on her.

participants.name: Michael Chen

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Tries to mediate between sisters, speaks calmly despite stress
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more focused on practical solutions
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'Let's figure out' and 'What we need to do' often
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Clears throat when trying to defuse tension

sample_dialogue: Let's figure out who can stay with Mom while Sarah finishes her shift.
What we need to do is make sure someone medical is checking on her regularly.
*clears throat* Sarah, I know you feel guilty, but Mom understands your job.

conversation_flow.description: Lisa calls in panic about mother's fall, Sarah immediately switches to clinical mode
Sarah gathers medical information while Lisa expresses frustration about her absence
Plan made for Michael to stay with mother, Sarah to call attending physician

specific_assignments.task: Call attending physician at mother's hospital to ensure proper care
specific_assignments.context: Use professional connections to ensure mother receives appropriate attention

specific_assignments.task: Stay with mother overnight and update family group text hourly
specific_assignments.context: Provide family presence and communication during Sarah's work obligations

scheduled_items.date_time: Tomorrow morning at 7:30 AM when Sarah's shift ends
scheduled_items.purpose: Discuss mother's care plan and long-term living arrangements

context.setting: Sarah's home office late evening after exhausting 12-hour shift
context.background: Daughter Emily failed chemistry test, teacher requesting parent conference about academic struggles
context.tension_point: Sarah's demanding work schedule vs. daughter's need for academic support and attention
context.expected_outcome: Address daughter's struggles while managing guilt about work-life balance

participants.name: Emily Chen

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Alternates between defensive and vulnerable, uses teen slang
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'It's not fair' and 'You don't understand' often
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice gets quieter when admitting struggles

sample_dialogue: It's not fair - everyone else's parents help them with homework but you're always at work.
You don't understand, Mom - chemistry is like impossible and Mr. Peterson hates me.
I tried to study but... *quietly* I don't know how to do it and you weren't here.

participants.name: Sarah Chen

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Tries to balance motherly concern with practical problem-solving
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more anxious about failing as a parent
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'We can figure out' and 'I'm worried about' frequently
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Rubs temples when feeling overwhelmed by competing demands

sample_dialogue: We can figure out a better study schedule - I'm worried about you falling behind.
Emily, I know I've been working a lot, but your education is so important to me.
What if we find you a tutor, and I'll try to be home earlier on weeknights?

participants.name: David Chen

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Speaks methodically about practical solutions and schedules
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more focused on logistics and coordination
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'Maybe we should' and 'What about if' often
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Checks calendar app while talking about scheduling

sample_dialogue: Maybe we should look at Emily's whole schedule - see where the time management issues are.
What about if I take over homework help on the nights Sarah's on call?
I've been thinking... maybe we need better communication about who's available when.

conversation_flow.description: Emily admits failing grade reluctantly, Sarah immediately feels guilty about work schedule
Discussion about study habits and parental availability, Emily opens up about feeling abandoned
Plan developed for tutoring and better family coordination of academic support

specific_assignments.task: Research chemistry tutors and schedule parent-teacher conference
specific_assignments.context: Need to address Emily's academic struggles with professional support

specific_assignments.task: Create family calendar showing who's available for homework help each night
specific_assignments.context: Need better coordination to ensure Emily has consistent academic support

scheduled_items.purpose: Discuss Emily's chemistry struggles and develop academic improvement plan

context.setting: Sarah's kitchen during rare evening off, wine glasses and takeout containers
context.background: Best friend Jessica going through messy divorce, making concerning decisions about custody and finances
context.tension_point: Sarah's medical training makes her see red flags, but Jessica won't listen to advice
context.expected_outcome: Maintain friendship while expressing serious concerns about Jessica's choices

participants.name: Jessica Martinez

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Talks rapidly when emotional, alternates between anger and hope
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more defensive and makes impulsive statements
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'I just want' and 'He doesn't deserve' frequently
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice gets higher when discussing ex-husband, gestures wildly

sample_dialogue: I just want him to suffer like he made me suffer - is that so wrong?
He doesn't deserve to see the kids after what he did to our family!
Sarah, you don't understand - I need to protect myself and the children from him.

participants.name: Sarah Chen

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Asks careful questions while trying not to sound preachy
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more clinical in analyzing Jessica's decisions
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'I'm concerned about' and 'What if' constantly
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Fidgets with wine glass when worried about Jessica's choices

sample_dialogue: I'm concerned about how this revenge approach might backfire in court, Jess.
What if keeping the kids from their father actually hurts them more in the long run?
Jessica, I love you, but some of these decisions seem... impulsive and potentially harmful.

participants.name: Tom Rodriguez

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Tries to inject practical perspective, speaks bluntly about legal realities
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more direct about tough love approach
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'Look, Jessica' and 'The reality is' often
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Leans back when Jessica gets emotional, maintains steady tone

sample_dialogue: Look, Jessica - I get that you're hurt, but this isn't helping your case.
The reality is, judges don't like parents who interfere with custody arrangements.
You need to think about what's best for your kids, not what makes you feel better.

conversation_flow.description: Jessica vents about ex-husband's latest transgression, friends listen supportively initially
Jessica reveals plans to violate custody agreement, Sarah and Tom express serious concerns
Tough love conversation about getting professional help and focusing on children's welfare

specific_assignments.task: Research family counselors and custody mediators to recommend to Jessica
specific_assignments.context: Jessica needs professional guidance to make better decisions for her family

scheduled_items.event: Follow-up coffee date to check on Jessica's progress
scheduled_items.purpose: Monitor Jessica's decision-making and provide continued support

context.setting: Sarah's car parked outside brother's apartment after emergency text message
context.background: Brother Mark lost job three months ago, hasn't told family, now facing eviction
context.tension_point: Mark's pride vs. Sarah's desire to help vs. concern about enabling bad financial habits
context.expected_outcome: Provide immediate assistance while establishing conditions for long-term support

participants.name: Mark Chen

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Speaks reluctantly, long pauses, admits things gradually
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more withdrawn and defensive about his choices
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'I didn't want to' and 'It's not that bad' often
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Avoids eye contact when discussing money, voice gets quieter

sample_dialogue: I didn't want to worry anyone - I thought I'd find something before it got this bad.
It's not that bad, Sarah... okay, maybe it is, but I can handle it myself.
*quietly* The eviction notice came yesterday - I've got five days to pay or move out.

participants.name: Sarah Chen

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Asks probing questions about finances while trying to stay supportive
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more systematic in analyzing the financial situation
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'How much exactly' and 'We need to understand' frequently
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Calculates numbers mentally while talking, looks worried

sample_dialogue: How much exactly do you owe in back rent, and what other debts are there?
We need to understand the full picture, Mark - I can't help if I don't know everything.
I'm worried about you, but I also need to make sure this doesn't happen again.

participants.name: David Chen

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Tries to balance support with practical reality checks
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more focused on creating sustainable solutions
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'What we can do' and 'Moving forward' often
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Leans forward when discussing solutions, uses reassuring tone

sample_dialogue: What we can do is help with the immediate crisis, but we need a plan going forward.
Moving forward, Mark, you've got to be honest with us about your situation.
We're family - we'll figure this out together, but no more hiding financial problems.

conversation_flow.description: Mark reluctantly admits to job loss and financial crisis, family expresses shock and concern
Full extent of financial problems discussed, family debates how much help to provide
Agreement to cover immediate needs with conditions about job search and financial transparency

specific_assignments.task: Apply for unemployment benefits and document all job search activities
specific_assignments.context: Condition for continued family financial support

specific_assignments.task: Research debt counseling services and budgeting resources for Mark
specific_assignments.context: Help Mark develop sustainable financial management skills

scheduled_items.event: Weekly family check-in on Mark's job search progress
scheduled_items.date_time: Every Sunday evening via video call
scheduled_items.purpose: Monitor job search progress and provide ongoing support and accountability

context.setting: Family dinner at parents' house, dishes cleared, serious conversation brewing
context.background: Sarah's father had minor fender-bender last week, family worried about his driving safety
context.tension_point: Father's independence vs. safety concerns vs. family responsibility for others on road
context.expected_outcome: Address driving safety without destroying father's dignity and autonomy

participants.name: Robert Chen Sr.

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Speaks defensively about his capabilities, uses past accomplishments
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more stubborn and dismissive of concerns
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'I've been driving' and 'You kids worry too much' often
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice gets firmer when independence is questioned

sample_dialogue: I've been driving for 50 years without any serious accidents - one little bump doesn't change that.
You kids worry too much - I know my limitations better than anyone else.
Taking away my car keys is like taking away my freedom - I won't be a prisoner in my own home.

participants.name: Sarah Chen

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Carefully presents medical concerns while respecting father's dignity
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more clinical to avoid emotional confrontation
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'Dad, I'm concerned about' and 'What if' frequently
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice gets gentler when discussing sensitive health topics

sample_dialogue: Dad, I'm concerned about reaction times and vision changes that come with aging - it's just biology.
What if we started with an eye exam and driving assessment - just to get a baseline?
I've seen too many families dealing with preventable accidents - I can't bear that happening to us.

participants.name: Linda Chen

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Tries to find middle ground solutions, speaks diplomatically
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more focused on practical compromises
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'What about' and 'Maybe we could' often
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Reaches out to touch father's hand when making suggestions

sample_dialogue: What about we compromise - you keep driving locally, but family drives for longer trips?
Maybe we could look into those refresher driving courses for seniors - not because you need it, but to stay current.
Robert, I worry too - what if something happened and you hurt someone else? You'd never forgive yourself.

conversation_flow.description: Sarah gently raises concerns about recent accident, father immediately becomes defensive
Family discusses aging and driving safety, father resists suggestions, mother tries to mediate
Agreement on gradual approach starting with medical and vision evaluations

specific_assignments.task: Research senior driving assessment programs and vision specialists
specific_assignments.context: Find respectful evaluation options that preserve father's dignity

specific_assignments.task: Schedule comprehensive eye exam and discuss concerns with family doctor
specific_assignments.context: Medical evaluation to determine if health issues are affecting driving ability

scheduled_items.event: Family meeting to review medical evaluation results
scheduled_items.date_time: After medical appointments, Sunday dinner next month
scheduled_items.purpose: Discuss evaluation results and make decisions about driving restrictions if needed
